body_html:
This is not the same problem. I can CRC check every record several times, and then suddenly one record, which could previously be read, fails. Running
sudo sh -c 'echo 3 >/proc/sys/vm/drop_caches'
temporally solve the problem, which show that the corruption happen in memory.
…
________________________________ From: siavash-khodadadeh <notifications@github.com> Sent: Monday, October 1, 2018 17:13 To: tensorflow/tensorflow Cc: stillwalker1234; Comment Subject: Re: [tensorflow/tensorflow] DataLossError (see above for traceback): corrupted record at 12 (#13463) I also encountered the same problem. There really was an issue with one of the TFRecord files I had. The way that I found it was to loop over all TFRecords and create a TFRecordDataset. Then I parsed them and just tried to access the data. I just printed the name of TFRecord files and then found the ones which were problematic. For me, it was because I was using a very large dataset and my hard drive limit on the cluster was met and my code created some corrupted TFRecords. — You are receiving this because you commented. body_text:
This is not the same problem. I can CRC check every record several times, and then suddenly one record, which could previously be read, fails.

Running
 sudo sh -c 'echo 3 >/proc/sys/vm/drop_caches'
temporally solve the problem, which show that the corruption happen in memory.
…
________________________________
From: siavash-khodadadeh <notifications@github.com>
Sent: Monday, October 1, 2018 17:13
To: tensorflow/tensorflow
Cc: stillwalker1234; Comment
Subject: Re: [tensorflow/tensorflow] DataLossError (see above for traceback): corrupted record at 12 (#13463)


I also encountered the same problem. There really was an issue with one of the TFRecord files I had. The way that I found it was to loop over all TFRecords and create a TFRecordDataset. Then I parsed them and just tried to access the data. I just printed the name of TFRecord files and then found the ones which were problematic. For me, it was because I was using a very large dataset and my hard drive limit on the cluster was met and my code created some corrupted TFRecords.

—
You are receiving this because you commented.

body:
This is not the same problem. I can CRC check every record several times, and then suddenly one record, which could previously be read, fails.

Running

> sudo sh -c 'echo 3 >/proc/sys/vm/drop_caches'

temporally solve the problem, which show that the corruption happen in memory.


________________________________
From: siavash-khodadadeh <notifications@github.com>
Sent: Monday, October 1, 2018 17:13
To: tensorflow/tensorflow
Cc: stillwalker1234; Comment
Subject: Re: [tensorflow/tensorflow] DataLossError (see above for traceback): corrupted record at 12 (#13463)


I also encountered the same problem. There really was an issue with one of the TFRecord files I had. The way that I found it was to loop over all TFRecords and create a TFRecordDataset. Then I parsed them and just tried to access the data. I just printed the name of TFRecord files and then found the ones which were problematic. For me, it was because I was using a very large dataset and my hard drive limit on the cluster was met and my code created some corrupted TFRecords.

—
